												Vice City is probably the best GTA that has been made to date. Obviously, as a PC gamer, this opinion does not include GTA V as that one was never released by Rockstar on my favourite platform. I personally liked GTA IV a lot and the reviews on the latest installment were very promising - I just think Vice City was more captivating than the rest.Vice City looks dated, yes. Please bear in mind that this is an eleven year old game and considering the capacity of our smart phones this game is accessible as an Android application as the game's engine can easily be handled by our phones' hardware. Its atmosphere, however, is still captivating even a decade after its release so playing such an "old" game on a widescreen monitor with next-gen hardware is no shame!You play as Tommy Vercetti (voice by Ray Liotta) and you are in the '80s. You have cars, music and even film references from this era. Some scenes remind you of Miami Vice while others are clearly a nod to Pacino's character in Scarface. How cool is that?You have dozens of missions available. Some continue the main story while other are just side missions. Each includes a cutscene with amazing voice acting so it is a crime to skip any of the available missions. Oh, you don't want to do any of these? No problem: Vice City allows the player to just cruise in the city, steal cars, crash these cars, harass citizens (with these cars, too). You can drive a cab and earn some money at your leisure. Or steal a police car and become the terminator of vigilantes.There are tons of things to do in GTA. And while Vice City is certainly an outdated game nothing else out there can remind you how cool the '80s were than this piece of treasure.

OverviewDespite its age, Grand Theft Auto: Vice City is still an extremely fun game. I have played every GTA game to date and despite my love for Grand Theft Auto 5, I still prefer Vice City and in the paragraphs below I will attempt to explain why.A Good Starting PointI love GTA 3. The game has quite a lot of enjoyable gameplay and during my most recent playthrough, I didn't have too many issues (besides the races), which was fairly impressive for a game of its age. This certainly does nor mean the game is amazing. In 2016 the game is both a bit clunky and also lacking aesthetic wise. The game was a good starting point and a great transition from the 2D gameplay of old into the 3D realm we know today. I understand how revolutionary GTA 3 was, however looking back in 2016 with the incredible GTA 5 out as well as some decent competitors such as Watch Dogs 2 and Mafia 3, GTA 3 doesn't stand up as well as it used to. Vice City (in my opion) does.Standing Up to Modern Open-World GamesOpen worlds are getting bigger and bigger as both time and hardware move forward. In an era full of games with huge landscapes that take hours to explore, revisiting Vice City was very refreshing. It takes about 10 minutes maximum to traverse the map and that is without counting for the race cars which can be found around every corner. I feel I have to truly get into a game in order to play it nowadays. You can't just sit down, do a quick mission and then leave again. This is mostly personal but a lot of Vice City's charm comes with its simplicity, in my eyes at least. Of course, the game isn't "simple" as I put it but compared to modern open world games it's far from complex; thats why I love the game. It's so easy just to do a few missions, save and quit. I think if the game tried to be complex it would've been left in the dust as time went by, but the games simplistic charm is what truly makes it timeless.GameplayAiming/ShootingMy main quarrel with this game is it's aiming mechanics and this is stemmed from the lack of over the shoulder aiming. Shooting accurately in third person is a pain. Let's say you have someone directly in front of you that you need to shoot. You aim your crosshair at them, but due to the camera angle, this makes you look at the ground missing your target. Instead, you aim above the target so you shoot straight in front of you (in theory). You shoot into the sky. This is quite easily fixed by scoping with the Assult Rifles however that makes 2/3s of weapons redundant. This is mainly a sign of age, however, the Assult Rifles spoke of earlier are not hard to find.Driving/FlyingDriving is very smooth for keyboard and mouse and is both playable and enjoyable. The flying is rather hard to get used to. In the modern day, it is rather rare to use the num pad to control anything let alone something as complex as a helicopter. It is very hard to control at first, however, upon getting used to can be fun to use. Boats are ok but a bit odd due to the physics engine.PhysicsThe physics engine for this game is both a bit clunky and also glitchy due to its age, however it is rare to have an issue with it in normal gameplay. Cars occasionally slide upon collision and some bigger vehicles can seem weightless and tip over but these issues are rare.The Story and MissionsThe story follows Tommy Vercetti as he is forced into the crime underworld of Vice City, a Miami-inspired metropolis filled to the brim with gangs, drugs and greed. You, through the eyes of Tommy, rise up through the criminal world and slowly build your empire gradually making more and more money. Admittedly the story can be a bit cheesy and predictable but this fits the pumped up 80s action film tropes that this game likes to both mock and mimic. Most missions are fun and interesting. You can go from stealing a phone from a gang of chefs to blowing up part of a mall and attempting to escape with a 5-star wanted level. Of course, a few missions are difficult and require multiple runs, but that just adds playtime.The EndThank you for reading my review. At the price this game goes for, I would recommend you pick it up. Who knows you might just fall in love all over again.

												So you might be asking why review a game that originally came out in 2002/2003? Well to this day it is still my favorite game. Nothing has come close to beating it and i don’t think anything ever will. There’s been a lot of controversy over the years about the Grand Theft Auto games, and their potential effects on children; so, this is probably a bad time to mention that I first played Vice City when I was quite young. But onto why I love the game so much: it’s probably a mixture of nostalgia and obsession. I believe that it would be in my top 5 games that I’ve spent the most time on (I’ve probably beaten it 12 times), and it’s quite ultimately the game I am the most familiar with.One of the more-objectively strong reasons why I love Vice City over the other GTA games is that Tommy Vercetti, as a main character, makes the most sense. It’s out of character for the majority of GTA characters to run around on a rampage. Vercetti is a sandpaper-rough, heartless shell of a man: he only wants to get the money back that was stolen from him, and he’ll work with whoever he can to achieve his goals. Some people may see him as a bit of a shallow character, but I’d rather that over a bad-guy-turned-good, like a lot of the other main characters in the GTA series. It just makes no sense for Niko (from GTA IV) to mow down dozens of pedestrians, when a lot of his dialogue is about the horrors of war back in his homeland, and how he is coming to the US to make himself a new life. Plus he first appears wearing a light blue-green Hawaiian shirt i mean what is there not to love.Much like the cast of characters, the story of Vice City worked so wonderfully because the developers threw it all against the backdrop of the nineteen eighties, which was in itself just a rip roaring time to be alive. At least that’s the impression one gets from games and television. You know, if you ignored the cold war, economic recession and the bad hairstyles. Vice City won in my eyes as it was a straight up gangster story. It certainly helped that it was basically a retelling of Scarface. If you’re going to make an 80s gangster movie there’s no better source material.Now onto the most-subjective reason why I love the game, even more so than pure nostalgia: the radio stations, or more specifically: V Rock. I still have the entire audio file of the station on my computer, and I’d listen to it separate from the game. I listen to it while i’m driving around today so that must count for something. V Rock is still for me the pinnacle of in game music. As someone who wasn’t that into music in my younger days, I can thank V Rock for introducing me to the bands I would still be listening to today. 2 Minutes to Midnight by Iron Maiden, Bark at the Moon from Ozzy, ♥♥♥ On Feel The Noize by Quiet Riot, Twisted Sister, Motley Crue and many more. Classic metal at its finest. It was also hosted by everyone’s favourite radio host Lazlow, of Chatterbox fame.This isn’t to say that Vice City is a perfect game, but then again I personally believe that a critical part of loving something is realising that it’s not perfect, and being okay with its faults. The game has some pretty obtrusive shooting controls, because of the early lock-on mechanic. It’s the same sort of issue that the other PS2-era GTAs had. This makes the shooting parts of gameplay quite unnecessarily hard. Not that I dislike a hard game, but I want to at least feel as though I am in control when I am getting the crap shot out of my character. To summarise, Vice City is a great combination of atmosphere, story, characters, and soundtrack. If you’re only familiar with the Grand Theft Auto games with fancy graphics on current-gen consoles, then you really should give Vice City a try. You can thank me later.

												"Welcome to Vice City, 1986. . . ."IntroductionGrand Theft Auto: Vice City. In a sense this is the game turned the franchise from a cult classic, to a game that everyone wanted. Since while in GTA, and GTA II, it was a top based shooter. There was no real story line, and general it was a cult game series. GTA III, it gave you a silent hero based in 2001. You suddenly were able to shoot in a 3-D environment, and had an actual story line. Well here in Vice City, they've take the formula that worked, and added more to it, so let's do it!Story 10/10The idea is you're Thomas Vercetti, a man who has just done 15 years in jail for "the family", your sent down south to buy some cocaine and get it back north. Well the deal goes south, and now you owe the 'family' a load of money, and you need the cocaine. As you investigate what happened, and you get your revenge. You'll see how Tommy changes in Vice City, from a hired gun, to something more. What I like about this story line, is that it's believable. Based on what I've found of the era (mid-80's), and the character profile we get of Tommy. Since if someone were thrown into his situation, with his connections. What he becomes is plausible, pending him getting arrested or killed. As a note here to the writers, they could've gone with some very immature humour, but when it does go funny, its done with a sense of class almost.Graphics 9/10I know some people are going to be screaming at me over this, since I gave the graphics a 9 rating over a 10. This game is 12 years old, and yes its aged well. I've seen modem games with worse graphics, at a higher price.Each gun, each car, even key people look unique. However, the problem is there are gaps where you see 'blue', and sometimes the details that separate two cars is so small you need to be the developer to see it. The other problem is running though trees, half the time Tommy is hidden from you. Which means you can't see him, and you see a 'blue' outline around the leafs.Sound & Music 11/10This is not a joke people. I am giving this game a 11/10 for music and sound. Since this is audio perfection. One of the reasons why I bought this game was for the in game radio. Besides the fashion, the radio music & chatter help set the mood for the game. You get an idea of what it was like to be in the 1980's. Where the cold war wasn't over yet, or how rap music was brand new. This is where you're going to get the real bang for your gaming dollar. Since I admit it, there are times I just load up the game, slap on a station as I do something else on my PC.Besides the music, you can listen to how a gun fires and you've got a good idea of what's being fired at you. Maybe you can't tell the difference between two Semi-automatics. However, if someone close to you is firing a pistol, and the guy next to him is using a shot gun. You can tell the difference, and when you're outgunned, that kind of information is handy.Game play 8/10I've got a few complains about the actual game engine per say. Sometimes the game lags for a few seconds when swapping radio stations, or exiting a vehicle. Other times, you can't see a 'target' circle on someone you're simpering, and when you pop off the shot it works. Who can forget that when firing from a vehicle, how there is no targeting circle. Its all guess and check. With the exception of when you're being driven by someone else.Now the beautiful part of this engine is how you've got to account for something moving. Most games if you're moving, you aim, you fire, you hit. In This game, you need to account for the motion of yourself, or the target, and sometimes both. The controls that are used are used in almost every game so the learning curve is not a long one.9/10

"Funny how?"Full of pop culture charm, sarcasm and blaring synthesisers, Rockstar's love letter to the likes of Goodfellas, Boogie Nights and Scarface really reflects the mastery of Vice City and the game's success. Voiced by none other than Ray "Henry freakin' Hill" Liotta, your journey as Tommy Vercetti through this '80s odyssey and crazed sea of neon lights, big hair and bright clothing features some of the best content that the GTA series has to offer.One of the reasons Rockstar Games continues to set and then decisively smash the standard for open-world wish fulfilment is because of just how brilliant their games are. Boasting an intellectual depth that far exceeds its critics, the GTA series in particular is yet to be equalled in humour and outright cynicism. I wouldn't be lying when saying that Rockstar continues to deliver some of the most relentlessly funny and cutting wit that's out there. I'll often stop playing to just listen and laugh at the latest crack at modern society. When there's better writing for radio station advertisements than the majority of real life television and cinema, it really shows just how great this series is. That's not to say that gameplay doesn't have something to do with it. The sheer amount of things to do, missions to complete and areas to explore here is astronomical, as is the case for the rest of the series. If you're looking for something to kill time with, then look no further. Old-school GTA has got you covered.Sure, the visuals have certainly aged, featuring blocky character models and low-res textures, but the rest of the game remains timeless. I’d wager that even the most stubborn of graphics diehards would soon become absorbed by the otherwise top-notch quality. With a tonne of varied environments and satisfying gameplay to boot, Vice City is just as good as it's modern counterparts. In the pre-San Andreas and GTA V world, there wasn't that much on offer in terms of the games we take for granted today, with most of the popular and ambitious titles back then confined mainly to the fantasy/role-playing market or the occasional narrative-driven FPS. Like the early days of cinema, crime was seen as taboo and highly controversial but - thankfully - titles such as GTA and Manhunt were set to change that, regardless of the backlash. A significant departure from the rather empty feel of GTA III, Vice City delivers yet again on what you'd expect from the series. The few noticeable flaws were mainly down to clipping or the occasional bug or glitch but nothing major. It's held up really well and remains popular for a reason. Whether stealing a tank from the military or attacking a fortress with a helicopter-mounted machinegun; from trying to hold out against the cops to being caught in a (relatively) high speed chase after a buggy while riding a bike with a blown-out tyre, this has it all. Better still? Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five’s ‘The Message’ was blasting all the while over the radio.Good times. All that and more awaits in Vice City.

												My favorite game in the franchise. Instead of silent protagonist Claude, you are now playing as Tommy Vercetti, charismatic member of Italian Mafia, who gets out of prison after serving 15 years for multiple killings. Soon enough he gets involved in a drug deal gone wrong and determines to find out who was behind it while building his own criminal empire.Setting is moved from cold streets of Liberty City to more relaxed Vice City which is based on Miami. References to 80's culture are numerous - disco music, pastel suits, styled cars. The American crack epidemic, drug trafficking and organized crime that followed it are heavily represented in the game, which also draws inspiration from many movies and tv series such as Miami Vice, Scarface, Carlito's Way, Godfather and many others. I will mention some examples:Retired colonel from Central America and drug trafficker Juan Cortez - parody of Manuel Noriega, Panama dictator and major player in drug trafficking during 80's.Drug baron Ricardo Diaz may be influenced by Frank Lopez, character from Scarface who happens to be played by late Robert Loggia who did voice acting for Ray Machowski, corrupt police officer in GTA 3. Diaz's mansion is very similar to Montana's from the same movie. Betrayal and the same clothes also add to the full picture. Interesting thing is that he is voiced by Luis Guzmán who played Gonzalo Rodríguez Gacha, drug trafficker and one of the leaders of the notorious Medellín Cartel in Netflix original series Narcos. Diaz's physical resemblance and temper to him are rather substantial.Ken Rosenberg's appearance and behaviour are nearly identical to David Kleinfeld, who was played by Sean Penn in Carlito's Way.Lance Vance is voiced by Philip Michael Thomas who played Ricardo Tubbs in Miami Vice, which heavily influenced Vice City.Tommy Vercetti was inspired by Tony Montana from Scarface. Memorable shootout scene was also incorporated.Last but not least there is Escobar International Airport, no need to say anything about that one.Game introduces bikes which are way more fun to drive than standard cars and will probably become your first choice in exploring the city. Later you get access to helicopters which are easy to control and are much better solution when you need a quick way to certain place, or you just want better view of the city. Those who prefer adventures on the sea are not forgotten, you can also drive boats.Major gangs in VC are Cubans, Haitians, Vice City Bikers and members of Forelli Crime Family. All of side activites from GTA 3 are also present here. Newly introduced are assets purchases. They include strip club, taxi company, film studio, dance club, printing works, car showroom, ice cream factory and boatyard. Each of them has a number of missions attached, and once all of them are complete a given property will begin generating an ongoing income.There is nine radio stations in the game - on seven of them you will listen great collection of licensed music, while talk shows that contain lots of satire are on remaining two. Big step was made compared to previous title in quantity of material - there is over 10 hours of it compared to 3.5h in GTA 3.Voice actors lineup and their performance is phenomenal; Ray Liotta, Tom Sizemore, Burt Reynolds, William Fichtner, Dennis Hopper and Danny Trejo are present among many others. One person that you certainly don't expect is porn actress Jenna Jameson, who gives voice to appropriately named character Candy Suxxx.Like its predecessor, Vice City was given a lot of GOTY awards and achieved huge commercial success, over 20 million sold copies speaks for itself. I really liked main character, and hope that Rockstar will bring him and Vice City setting back in the future.

												GTA Vice City, a game created by Rockstar North (Edinburgh, Scotland), which was released a year after the release of GTA III, on October 2002 for the PS2, and later ported to PC in May 2003.StoryThis time around, the game was based in Vice City, which resembles Miami.You are playing as Tony, a member of the Forelli Family, which is based in Liberty City. The Don decided to expand its borders, so they give you huge ton of money and send you to Vice City to make a deal. Unfortunately, you get ambushed. All the money is lost and now you have to find a way to pay them back.GTA Vice City solved all the issues that the 3rd one had. They doubled the amount of vehicles[gta.wikia.com], songs in radio stations and weapons. They even added flyable helicopters and a plane to the game.The solved the issues with gangs being hostile towards you. For those that don't remember, 5 out of 7 gangs would be hostile towards you by the end of the game in GTA 3. It became really annoying considering that some gangs had shotguns which could blow up your car in 2 shots. Well, in Vice City, there would be only 1 gang that would be hostile to you.The plot itself is also very enjoyable, unlike GTA 3. It has a very cool feel to it, as if i am in some Al Pacino movie. Just watch a few minutes of it and you may understand why.


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



Comparison to its predecessor - GTA IIIThey added more game mechanics. You could damage cars with melee weapons, shoot the tires (the cops would even have spiked strips during chases), and now you are able to shoot through windows of a car, giving you the ability to kill the driver.They added the ability to wear outfits (some areas, like the police station can only be accessed with such uniforms).They added motorcycles.They added assets and safehouses which can be bought. Assets would have a set of missions that if you complete, you would get profit from. Safehouses would allows you to save your game and store additional cars in the garage. GTA III had only 3 safehouses, which are unlocked as you progress through the story. Well in Vice City, you get 9.They also added a few helicopters, and a plane that was actually flyable this time.The amount of weapons increased, usually each weapon tier would give you a choice of about 3 weapons. But the biggest change was the addition of melee weapons. Unlike GTA III, where you only had a baseball bat, in Vice City you get to play with katanas, chainsaws, screwdrivers, machetes, golf clubs and so on.Unlike GTA 3, Vice City featured a full map that you could view, and icons were visible throughout the whole game.They added the ability to crouch. Most of the time i see some one playing older GTAs, most of them never use that mechanic. Well, let me clear some things out for you. Most objects in GTA, even cars, are made that way, so that when the player crouches, it fully covers him. But when you are starting the firing animation, your character will rise a bit above his cover. So in a way, this is kind of like the Gears of War cover system.Now most people don't understand the importance of this mechanic. If you played GTA III, you probably know that there weren't a lot of shootouts. Most of the game, you are using your cars for your missions. Well, the crouching mechanic changed that, making at least 50% of game involve shootouts.If you really planning on completing every mission in the game, you need to learn to take cover.Do i recommend it?Well, this is probably the only game that is set in the 80's period. The songs in the radio, the cars, the city itself - the game is just so good at capturing the feel of the 80s. This is definitely a gem.As always, the PC port suffers with the same issues as in GTA III. Mouse problems and FPS locked to 30. Most glitches can be fixed with SilentPatch, which i suggest you install before playing.Other than that, this is the 2nd game of the GTA III era, which are all connected. And chronologically, plot wise, they are set in this order:1986 - Vice City1992 - San Andreas2001 - GTA III

As they settle the deal, they are ambushed by several armed and masked men, who kill Victor and Tommy's bodyguards. Tommy narrowly escapes with Ken from the docks, and as a result, he ultimately loses both Forelli's money and the cocaine in the process. Ken drives to his office, while Tommy returns to his hotel.[6]When Tommy informs Sonny of the ambush, Sonny loses his temper and threatens Tommy with the consequences of attempting to cheat the Mafia. Tommy promises to retrieve the money and the cocaine and kill whoever was responsible for the ambush.[7] Towards this end, Tommy meets up again with Ken at his office, who leads Tommy to retired Colonel and mid-level drug dealer named Juan Garcia Cortez, who was Victor Vance's contact and who organised the deal between the Vances and the Forellis. Cortez expresses regret about Tommy's bad deal and promises that his own lines of inquiry are being made to find out who masterminded the ambush plot. Tommy also meets Cortez's daughter Mercedes, who becomes Tommy's confidante shortly thereafter.While Tommy waits for the outcome of Cortez's investigation, he meets cocky 21-year old British record producer Kent Paul, real estate mogul Avery Carrington, and a mysterious man, who introduces himself as Lance Vance, younger brother of Victor and the underboss of the now-defunct Vance Crime Family, who wants revenge for the death of his brother and also wants the Vance Crime Family back on the map.[8]As time passes, Tommy befriends Cortez and begins to do regular work for him as an errand boy and hitman. On one such job, Tommy is called in with Lance to protect the deal of a drug baron named Ricardo Diaz during a deal with the Cubans, looking to buy some high-end cocaine. During the deal, Diaz is ambushed by a gang of Haitians, but Tommy is able to kill them and save the deal, as well as Diaz's life. Consequently, Diaz begins hiring Tommy for his own agenda. 												Tommy Vercetti, a loyal former member of the Forelli Family, has just been released in 1986, serving 15 years for killing 11 men in the Harwood District of Liberty City in early 1971, earning him the nickname The Harwood Butcher.[3] Tommy's old boss, Sonny Forelli, fears that Tommy's presence in Liberty City will heighten tensions between the other Liberty City families and bring unwanted attention to his organisation's criminal activities.[4]To prevent this from happening, Sonny ostensibly promotes Tommy to a capo and sends him to Vice City under the guardianship of a crooked lawyer and Sonny's contact Ken Rosenberg to act as their buyer for a series of cocaine deals for Sonny, whose interest is to expand his family activities down the South and to overrun the Liberty drug market with the high-end cocaine from Vice City, hoping to create a monopoly on the Liberty City drug ring to establish the Forelli Crime Family on the top.[5]Soon, Tommy and his bodyguards are awaited at the Escobar International Airport by Ken, who gives them an info about the deal and takes them to the docks, where they are awaited by the Vance Crime Family, prominent drug kingpins of Vice City led by Victor Vance, who arrive in the chopper with Diaz. As they settle the deal, they are ambushed by several armed and masked men, who kill Victor and Tommy's bodyguards. Tommy narrowly escapes with Ken from the docks, and as a result, he ultimately loses both Forelli's money and the cocaine in the process. Ken drives to his office, while Tommy returns to his hotel.[6]When Tommy informs Sonny of the ambush, Sonny loses his temper and threatens Tommy with the consequences of attempting to cheat the Mafia. Tommy promises to retrieve the money and the cocaine and kill whoever was responsible for the ambush.[7] Towards this end, Tommy meets up again with Ken at his office, who leads Tommy to retired Colonel and mid-level drug dealer named Juan Garcia Cortez, who was Victor Vance's contact and who organised the deal between the Vances and the Forellis. Cortez expresses regret about Tommy's bad deal and promises that his own lines of inquiry are being made to find out who masterminded the ambush plot. Tommy also meets Cortez's daughter Mercedes, who becomes Tommy's confidante shortly thereafter.While Tommy waits for the outcome of Cortez's investigation, he meets cocky 21-year old British record producer Kent Paul, real estate mogul Avery Carrington, and a mysterious man, who introduces himself as Lance Vance, younger brother of Victor and the underboss of the now-defunct Vance Crime Family, who wants revenge for the death of his brother and also wants the Vance Crime Family back on the map.[8]As time passes, Tommy befriends Cortez and begins to do regular work for him as an errand boy and hitman. On one such job, Tommy is called in with Lance to protect the deal of a drug baron named Ricardo Diaz during a deal with the Cubans, looking to buy some high-end cocaine. During the deal, Diaz is ambushed by a gang of Haitians, but Tommy is able to kill them and save the deal, as well as Diaz's life. Consequently, Diaz begins hiring Tommy for his own agenda. Tommy takes this work because it pays well, in spite of his distaste for Diaz. On another errand for Cortez, he plans to meet a French courier to retrieve missile chips stolen from the French government. The deal is ambushed by several French agents and Tommy later kills the courier, who fled the ambush with the chips, retrieving the items.Tommy learns from Cortez that Cortez's own lieutenant, Gonzalez, was partially responsible for the ambush on Tommy's cocaine deal since he is the only person besides Cortez to know about the deal, and Cortez asks Tommy to kill Gonzalez as a favour, since he was a man who he did distrust and was working behind his back. Afterwards, Cortez voices his suspicion that Diaz might have been behind the ambush. Tommy initially continues the status quo to prepare for his attack, but his hand is forced when Lance attempts to take revenge by himself and fails, forcing Tommy to rush across the city and rescue him from the junkyard in which he is held. With the die cast, the two move quickly to raid Diaz's mansion and execute Diaz. With Diaz dead, and Colonel Cortez fleeing the country to escape the French, the established drug empires in Vice City quickly crumble and Tommy and Lance personally take over, becoming Vice City's drug kingpins.Tommy becomes the head of his own organisation, the Vercetti Crime Family, distancing himself from the Forelli Family and Liberty City and more interested in personally controlling Vice City than being Forelli's puppet. But the more powerful and rich Tommy gets, the more Lance begins to exhibit paranoia and sociopathic behaviours, to the point that he begins to abuse his own bodyguards and constantly calls Tommy in states of hysteria, losing his mind over being just a powerless second-in-command as he was under his brother for the past 2 years. Tommy begins to suspect that Lance is up to something.Tommy makes alliance with Umberto Robina's Cubans against Auntie Poulet's Haitians, even though he is at the same time hypnotised by Poulet's voodoo into helping the Haitians as well. However, Tommy and Poulet part ways Tommy and the Cubans sneak explosives into the Haitian drug factory disguised in Haitian gang cars and blow it up, effectively ending the conflict and putting the Haitians out of business, enabling the Cubans to take over Little Havana. Umberto then becomes Tommy's partner. He also becomes friends with Big Mitch Baker, a leader of the biker gang and a Vietnam veteran, with both the bikers and the Cubans becoming protectors of Vercetti family business.As his drug business expands, Tommy buys assets in nearly bankrupt companies such as a car lot named Sunshine Autos, a cab depot Kaufmann Cabs, a popular night club called The Malibu, a local boathouse, a print shop, Print Works, an ice-cream company, and an adult film company, all of which he turns back into competitive businesses. He also becomes a personal bodyguard to glam metal band Love Fist, and pulls a major bank heist. He starts to control almost all the assets and ties of Vice City: Sunshine Autos as a chop shop, Kaufmann Cabs for money laundering, The Malibu Club for dispatching drugs, the ice-cream company for the production of drugs and the film company to control the underground movie scene.Eventually, the Forelli family discovers that Tommy has gained control over entire Vice City and without having sent a single dime back to them. Sonny is enraged that Tommy has become independent and is hustling him, and sends collectors consisting of high-ranking Forelli members to force money out of Tommy's assets. Tommy disposes of them, but after they injure the elderly operator of his print shop of counterfeit money, he decides to cut Sonny and the Forelli family out of his business, severing his ties with the Forelli family.An angered Sonny arrives in Vice City with a small army of mafiosi, intent on taking their tribute by force. Sonny and his henchmen soon arrive at the Vercetti Estate. Just as Tommy attempts to give them their tribute in counterfeit money, Sonny reveals he is the one who set Tommy up fifteen years before, sending him to kill the eleven men who were expecting him since he was feeling that Tommy would himself take over Sonny's business. Lance then exposes himself as a traitor, revealing Tommy's attempt to fool Sonny, and also admitting to informing Sonny about Tommy's activities in Vice City. Lance explains that he did it because Tommy started to disown him and didn't treat him equally, and wanted him dead so he could rebuild the Vance Crime Family and the fortune he had with his brother. An enraged Tommy starts a gunfight.In the ensuing battle, Tommy first chases, ridicules, and finally kills Lance, then storms downstairs, where he faces off with Sonny,

												GTA 3 is great, but GTA Vice City is greater. Vice City takes what GTA 3 established, preserved it, improved it and added to it. Taking place in 1986 Vice City, you play as Italian American mobster Tommy Vercetti. Immediately upon arriving in Vice City, a deal that was supposed to establish him in the city is attacked, forcing him to leave the goods at the site. The rest of the game involves rising up, killing the man responsible for the attack, obtaining a mansion, killing your former boss and ally, and ruling Vice City. Perhaps the best part of Vice City for me is the soundtrack. Containing many songs from artists like Toto, Hall and Oates, Michael Jackson, Laura Branigan and Foreigner, along with two complete talk show stations, Vice City will keep you busy in the audio department. Unlike the soundtrack of GTA 3 which mostly consisted of stereotypical late 90s pop music and typically left me only tuning to Flashback FM with its Scarface soundtrack, Vice City sometimes left me driving around just to listen to the great music or VCPR, its guests and its bitter Hispanic host, Maurice Chavez. If none of that fascinates you, the PC version supports a custom radio station. Just drag your .mp3 files into its folder, and you can drive to your own music. Sadly, due to the vast amount of copyrighted music, rights expire, and songs are lost. This song being Lionel Richie's "Running With the Night", which was present on the PS2 version but absent from the PC version. Compared to GTA 3, there is alot more things to have and to do. Motorcycles, helicopters and alot more boats are the firsts in the vehicle department. Many more weapons, like revolvers, chainsaws, hammers, combat shotguns, submachine guns, assault rifles, sniper rifles and even screwdrivers are some of the new additions. A lot more is also added mechanic wise, like the ability to dive out of cars, crouch and aim properly are some new additions. Vice City itself is quite beautiful, with many neon, art deco buildings and skyscrapers can be found in the city. Most buildings in the game are just low res textures, but the interiors you could enter are beautiful, like the mansion, the hotel room, the dance club and the strip club. Perhaps the biggest change between GTA 3 and Vice City is the addition of a speaking protagonist. Not only does Tommy Vercetti have a lot more personality and charm, he is more likeable. Another addition is the ability to buy safehouses and businesses. In GTA 3, you are given a safehouse on each island but that is about it. In addition to being more convenient, the latter is also fun and necessary. After killing the man who set you up, you can buy up various businesses around Vice City, like a Car Dealership, a Boatyard, a Strip Club, a Pornography movie studio and a dance club. All of these businesses set up fun missions with them. For example, the dance club opens up a series of bank heist missions, the boatyard opens up a long stunt course, and the car dealership opens up a mission to retrieve certain cars on a list, which will get you both a monetary reward and a bunch of fast cars, like a DeLorean or a race car. There is alot more in Vice City that just have to be seen to be believed. Some features of the PC version include the ability to aim with any weapon, the ability to change the player's skin and, as I mentioned, the ability to make a custom radio station. For the money, Vice City is definitely worth it. Buy it.

												GTA Vice City is a great game and maybe you've played it before on the PS2 or Xbox. This is less of a review and more of a, "here's what you need to get it running perfectly on PC." Because, by default, it doesn't support widescreen resolutions, you need to force v-sync, it has a number of bugs that can be fixed using a patch,Let's start with the controller. This modder, Silent, is a diety. They've done so much for the classic GTA games. They modded the GInput inputs for 360 controllers so that the 360 controller button will actually appear on screen, not to mention function since Rockstar really didn't bother with controller support for the PC versions. Also, the controllers can be set to the style of GTA IV gameplay. This mod has full support of other controllers as well, such as the Dualshock and most certainly Logitech controllers. I haven't tried the Steam controller on it though. Download it here: http://www.gtagarage.com/mods/show.php?id=24272, you'll be able to pick out Vice City from the options given. Once download, just unzip and follow the instructions.To get GTA Vice City working in widescreen, you will need to download a fix from ThirteenAG. It's extremely simple. Just download, unzip, and read the instructions. https://thirteenag.github.io/wfp#gtavc You'll also see widescreen fixes for GTA III and San Andreas if you haven't gotten to those.To force v-sync, it's going to depend on whether or not you're using an AMD or Nvidia card. I have an AMD R9 280, so if you have an AMD card, you're going to want to access the Radeon settings, go to the gaming tab, find Vice City, click it, find a tab that says "Wait for Vertical Refresh", hit the drop down arrow, you want it set to always on. On an Nvidia card, you want to open the Nvidia control panel, go to 3D settings, find Vice City from the drop down bar, select it, scroll down til you find v-sync, and same thing, set it to always on.The SilentPatch is necessary if you want good lighting and shadowing. http://www.gtagarage.com/mods/show.php?id=25368, you have your options to choose from the classic GTA games, but be sure to also download the DDraw patch from the same set of downloads. It improves the draw distance. Download both files, extract, and read the instructions.That should be about it. I hope you enjoy the game as it is quite a lot of fun. Brilliant soundtrack. Good story. Fun side missions (asset missions). Doesn't take itself too seriously. It's a solid 9.0/10

												GTA Vice City - A true, timeless masterpiece, that has endured the test of time and is still one of the best games in the series.Just like all older games, this one does not strike you with stunning visuals, like the newer additions in the series like GTA IV and V. But graphics is not all about a game. GTA Vice City offers a great story, characters and the feeling of freedom in its beautiful open-world city, that only few other games manage to capture. The refferences to the pop culture of the 80s are to be found literaly everywhere in Vice City, which accomplishes the atmosphere of the 80s' Miami, which the game aims to recreate in its own unique style.  The style of the people that you see in the streets, the cars, the buildings' architecture and the scenery all help you immerse with the game and makes you feel as if you are watching a movie, rather than playing a game.The soundtrack that Rockstar have compiled is divine, topping even those from the newer entries in the GTA series. All the radio stations in the game are absolutely fantastic with songs from the titans of the 80s' musical scene like Michael Jackson, Ozzy Osbourne, Mr. Mister, Toto, INXS, Laura Brannigan and many others. Even if you don't like this kind of music, the game will make you fall in love with it. But there's more - the radio stations' DJs will make you laugh all the time with their comments on topics that satirize different aspects of the life in the 80s. And the commercials too!The story of the game is also brilliant. As if it is directly taken from a classical gangster movie. Filled with action, twists and many great characters you will be thrilled from the start and until the very end. But even after the completion of all the story missions you will have to spend many more hours if you want to unlock 100% of the game. The game will offer you more than at least 20 hours of sheer fun, but no doubt you will want to come back again and play it over and over again. But if you don't like playing by the rules, you will still be able to find lots of fun things to do. Steal a car, go on a rampage, attain a six-star wamted level and have some fun blowing up police and military vehicles and shooting SWAT teams with tons of great weapons, as they try to stop you.More than 10 years after its initial release GTA Vice City is still the excellent game it used to be. If you have not had the chance to play the game until now, do not hesitate and get it right away.10/10 points for an amazing game!

												It's the eighties, do a lot of coke and vote for Ronald Reagan.Almost everything about this game is perfect, even on PC. Despite being one of the earlier PC ports of the 3D GTA titles it's relatively easy to control. There's a surprisingly large amount of graphics options for such an old game and especially one to come out in this time period when consoles were king in developers' eyes, so kudos to Rockstar for actually thinking this out.I really think that the 80's are the perfect decade for GTA. The decade of decadence. Crime was getting more common, drugs were getting harder and easier to get, and the media was getting more violent. It was a time of total unhindered immoral activity. It basically screams Grand Theft Auto.The soundtrack is amazing. I'm really into heavy metal and new wave, so I'm very biased when it comes to this kind of thing, but trust me, there's nothing like running over pedestrians in a muscle car while listening to Iron Maiden's "Two Minutes to Midnight" or fleeing from the police in a taco truck while blasting "Video Killed The Radio Star" by The Buggies.There's a wide variety of melee weapons, and while the guns are nice I think the wide variety of weapons such as the chainsaw (straight out of Scarface) and a ♥♥♥♥♥ really set the tone for the game.Tommy Vercetti is also a great character. He's beautifully two dimensional and the writers didn't try to ♥♥♥♥♥foot around that. He's a cold blooded Mafia hit man who's been released from prison after killing 11 guys and he's still ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off. He's not an Anti Hero like Niko Bellic who's just trying to get the American Dream, nor is he an Anti Hero like CJ who's trying to protect his neighborhood from drugs and rival gangs. He's just a really bad guy. If you cross him, he will kill you. If you mess up a job he's on, he will kill you. If you don't pay him, you guessed it, he will kill you. It's that simple. His American Dream is making others' lives a nightmare.However, there are two things I don't like about this game though. One is the graphics. The models, especially the character models, are terrible. They haven't aged well, and the game was obviously made in 2002. This is especially noticeble when the various "sexy" female characters are onscreen, because while they are obviously human, they basically look like they had their breasts and hips glued on. The wacky 80's hairstyles have a simaler problem, as do the brightly colorerd clothes that the majority of the main characters (and Tommy himself) wear. They look as if they've been painted or nailed on to some kind of puppet or mannequin. I honestly think that the models in System Shock 2 looked better than this.The second thing is the lack of multiplayer. Add the fact that MultiTheftAuto is terrible and you have a huge problem. I understand that when Vice City came out, the main focus was on the PS2, which at that time still didn't have online multiplayer capabilites, so it is forgivable, but still, it's disappointing.Overall, I think this is the greatest Grand Theft Auto game out there. Yes, even better than San Andreas. It's just totally tubular.

												For many people Vice City is still the best GTA game today. I personally prefer San Andreas, but there's no doubt that Vice City is a masterpiece, surpassing San Andreas in both the setting (80's Miami) and music (fitting this setting nicely). Vice City improved on GTA III by adding a nice story with a better protagonist and side characters, expanding the soundtrack, improving the shooting mechanics, adding motorbikes and helicopters (now you have a Hunter to cause chaos alongside the Rhino) and a lot more side content with more rewards. It's also easier, meaning that you can have a good time for longer without dying or getting busted. The map also feels more well designed and consistent, and the mission variety is also nice. In the end, Vice City was and still is a brilliant game, among other GTA's and on it's own.Again, i recommend you to install at least SilentPatch fo fix bugs and issues, and the Widescreen Fix if you use a widescreen and GInput if you wish to play it with a controller.

												Grand Theft Auto: Vice City.One of the best games in the 3D universe era of the GTA series. I used to play this game when I was younger. A portion of my childhood revolves around the classic GTA trilogy. When you're not on a mission, feel free to cause some havoc. Do whatever the hell you want without a care in the world, that is until the vigilance of the police puts a stop to your terror. The 1980's aesthetics and the overall atmosphere of the game are very pleasing to look at and the different radio stations you can listen to feature a lot of classic hits that are just wonderful to listen to as you play.I give this game a 9/10. Who cares if its graphics don't fit with today's style? Graphics don't determine if a game is good or not. It looks really nice, especially for its time, making its debut in late 2002. The early 2000's brought a lot of great games into existence, each unique and diverse in their own ways. GTA: Vice City has a lot of replay value with its various side missions, there's just so much you can do outside of the main story line. There's also 100 secret packages scattered throughout the world. Try to find them all, and you'll be rewarded handsomely with an arsenal of mass destruction and luxurious vehicles.My only problem with this game is that sometimes you can get stuck under a vehicle or rock and it's impossible to get out until you respawn or load the game from a save slot, and while there are a few other gamebreaking glitches, those only happen if the player makes them happen. Overall, this game is a bundle of fun and I definitely recommend it to anyone who hasn't played a GTA game before or just for nostalgic purposes.

												This has to be my favorite game out of the 3D Universe in the GTA Series, if you don't know what 3D Universe means let me explain, Grand Theft Auto, Grand Theft Auto London 1961 and 1969, and Grand Theft Auto 2 are the 2D Universe, Grand Theft Auto III, Grand Theft Auto Vice City, Grand Theft Auto San Andreas, Grand Theft Auto Advance, Grand Theft Auto Liberty City Stories, and Grand Theft Auto Vice City Stories are the 3D Universe, Grand Theft Auto IV, Grand Theft Auto EFLC, Grand Theft Auto Chinatown Wars, and Grand Theft Auto V are teh HD Universe. Anyway, back to Vice City, while GTA III was the first GTA I played and GTA San Andreas I played a little more, GTA Vice City is more fun for me. The story begins with Tommy Vercetti doing a regular drug deal with Victor Vance and Lance Vance for Sonny, Tommy's Boss, until Diaz's Men ambush them and gun down two of Tommy's body guards and Victor as Tommy, Ken Rosenberg, and Lance Vance all escape. Tommy breaks the news to Sonny who is angry and demends Tommy to get him the money back for the drugs, (Tommy dropped the drugs when Diaz's Men started shooting and ran away leaving the drugs) Tommy promises he will and the game really begins. All thoughout the game Tommy gets involved in a lot of fun missions, some of my favorites are when (Spoiler Alert Coming, Skip to Next Paragraph if you Haven't Finished All the Missions Yet!) Tommy and Lance break into Diaz's Mansion and gun down all of Diaz's henchmen and kill Diaz, when Tommy saves Lance from Diaz's Men  in the Junkyard which was one hard mission but gives you a sense of success after beating it, when Tommy and Lance dress as cops and plant the bomb in the mall, the Bank Heist, and the final mission where all kinds of stuff happens! The soundtrack is amazing! I mostly listened to Flash FM and Emotion but man, never once was there a bad song and I can listen to all of those stations even the talk show without getting tired of it like GTA V. (GTA V still has an okay soundtrack though but I really only liked Radio Mirror Park, Rebel Radio, and the Radio Talk Shows) You still can't swim which kind of sucks but they have added helicopters, motorcycles, and a sea plane since GTA III. The story is pretty good, the characters are what really made it for me though, Tommy Vercetti has to be my favorite protaginist from the GTA Series, wish he appeared in GTA San Andreas but oh well. Anyway, GTA Vice City is a classic and I hope GTA VI takes place in Vice City so we can experience an HD Vice City. 												Grand Theft Auto: Vice City.One of the best games in the 3D universe era of the GTA series. I used to play this game when I was younger. A portion of my childhood revolves around the classic GTA trilogy. When you're not on a mission, feel free to cause some havoc. Do whatever the hell you want without a care in the world, that is until the vigilance of the police puts a stop to your terror. The 1980's aesthetics and the overall atmosphere of the game are very pleasing to look at and the different radio stations you can listen to feature a lot of classic hits that are just wonderful to listen to as you play.I give this game a 9/10. Who cares if its graphics don't fit with today's style? Graphics don't determine if a game is good or not. It looks really nice, especially for its time, making its debut in late 2002. The early 2000's brought a lot of great games into existence, each unique and diverse in their own ways. GTA: Vice City has a lot of replay value with its various side missions, there's just so much you can do outside of the main story line. There's also 100 secret packages scattered throughout the world. Try to find them all, and you'll be rewarded handsomely with an arsenal of mass destruction and luxurious vehicles.My only problem with this game is that sometimes you can get stuck under a vehicle or rock and it's impossible to get out until you respawn or load the game from a save slot, and while there are a few other gamebreaking glitches, those only happen if the player makes them happen. Overall, this game is a bundle of fun and I definitely recommend it to anyone who hasn't played a GTA game before or just for nostalgic purposes.
